description_narrative: The Project aims to increase safety and security for people in EO affected communities, to increase preparedness and protection of communities and strengthen national mine action structures to address EO contamination in compliance with IMAS.
conditions_condition_narrative: Social and environmental sustainability will be enhanced through application of the UNDP Social and Environmental Standards (http://www.undp.org/ses) and related Accountability Mechanism (http://www.undp.org/secu-srm).
result_indicator_title_narrative: Output Indicator
By 2024, 75% of previously mined land now in productive or social use.
By 2024, draft National standards submitted to the CHDE Board.
CHDE is equipped with modern and up-to-date EOD and detection equipment to operate safely according to IMAS (transportation, detection and protective equipment, communication tools, etc.)
Number of CHDE staff (30% women) is trained in Explosive ordnance disposal (non-cumulative)
Number of CHDE staff (50% women) trained in first aid /medical emergency
CHDE field deployment planning and operations (EOD, RE, LR) are supported by international technical advisors
CHDE headquarters and Training Center are refurbished
CHDE knowledge on best international practices increased
Key stakeholders in EO sector are involved in the NMACP with strong coordination mandate
Frequency of meetings hold by NMACP to facilitate coordination in the mine action programme
Number consultations, coordination meetings and joint actions with other institutions realized.
Key operators in Mine Action pillars are engaged in WGs.
Frequency of working group meetings for coordination of interventions
Risk education materials and knowledge products are developed according to IMAS, addressing children, youth, women and men.
Victim Information System (VIS) is developed and updated
Number of climate-resilient and gender-responsive shelters are constructed and/or renovated, rehabilitated, furnished and equipped
Draft National strategy and operational plans submitted to the CHDE Board
LR and EOD operation plans are developed and submitted to the CHDE Board.
Deliver  the annual work plan at the level of above 85%,
result_indicator_description_narrative:
1.a. Percentage of compliance of key operations as per International Mine Action Standards (IMAS)
1.b. Percentage of satisfaction with national mine survey regulation by key national and local actors
2.a. Availability of inclusive, active and open coordination mechanism for mine action pillars and operational for explosive ordinance
2.b. Availability of Information sharing and coordination mechanisms with multilateral institutions.
2.c. Operation of cooperation mechanism with multilateral institutions
3.a. Number of accidents due to explosive ordinance in the affected communities reduced 
3.b. Availability of gender aspect analyzed and mainstreamed in the project
By 2024, 75% of previously mined land now in productive or social use.
By 2024, draft National standards submitted to the CHDE Board.
By 2023, CHDE is equipped with modern and up-to-date EOD and detection equipment to operate safely according to IMAS (transportation, detection and protective equipment, communication tools, etc.)
By 2023, at least 10 CHDE staff (30% women) is trained in EOD Level 2/3 and other mine action pillars according to IMAS.
By 2023, at least 10 CHDE staff (50% women) is trained in first aid /medical emergency.
By 2024, all CHDE field deployment planning and operations (EOD, RE, LR) are supported by international technical advisors.
By 2024, CHDE headquarters and Training Center are refurbished in a location and facility provided by the Government.
By 2024, the knowledge of the CHDE leadership on best international practices and instruments for management and coordination of MA sector is increased.
By 2023, all key stakeholders in EO sector  are involved in the NMACP with strong coordination mandate

By 2024, National Mine Action Coordination Platform (NMACP) holds quarterly meetings to facilitate coordination in the mine action programme (by sub-sectors) and reports back to their institutions regularly
By 2024, at least 6 consultations, coordination meetings and joint actions with other institutions realized.
By 2023, all key operators in Mine Action pillars are engaged in WGs.
By 2024, WGs meet on monthly basis to coordinate the interventions, monitor the activities and evaluate the results in specific Mine Action pillars.
By 2024, RE materials and knowledge products are developed according to IMAS, addressing children, youth, women and men.

By 2024, Victim Information System (VIS) is updated and provides more comprehensive, higher quality, duly disaggregated and reliable data for improved service delivery, referrals, policy monitoring and policy formulation.

By 2024, at least five climate-resilient and gender-responsive shelters are constructed and/or renovated, rehabilitated, furnished and equipped, each able to accommodate at least 50 residents, including women, children, aged people, persons with disabilities,
By 2023, draft National strategy and operational plans submitted to the CHDE Board.
By 2023, the LR and EOD operation plans are developed and submitted to the CHDE Board and are utilizing the NTS results in four target regions
Deliver  the annual work plan at the level of above 85%,
result_indicator_baseline_comment_narrat:
1.a. Baseline to be set via compliance assessments conducted in 2023
1.b. Baseline to be set via assessment in 2023
2.a  Coordination mechanism for mine action pillars not available (2022)
2.b. Information sharing and coordination mechanism with multilateral institutions not available (2022)
2.c. No cooperation (2022)
3.a  1 accident (official statistics, 2021)
3.b. Information on gender dimension not available (2021)
No national strategy and operational plans exist
result_indicator_period_actual_comment_n: The Project is in a start-up period.

100% of previously mined lands in Jermuk and Geghamasar communities, 41% of Sotk community and 8% of Kechut are cleaned from mines, cluster munitions and other explosive ordnance and are now in productive/ social use.
National Mine Action Standards (NMAS) have been revised and updated.

CHDE is equipped with 10 magnetic locator probe for EO subsurface search, 8 metal detectors, 13 mine detectors, 4 medical trauma kits, 6 laser rangefinders, 6 lensatic/prismatic compass, 6 GPS-s, 4 vegetation trimmers, 410 batteries, 8 chargers to operate safely in the field in compliance with IMAS.
CHDE was equipped also with 14 laptops, 14 PC displays, 11 printers, 4 projectors with screens, 3 smart TV-s.
International technical adviser/international consultant supported CHDE in planning and operations.
To be reported in 2024
CHDE HQ and training center are being renovated and refurbished.
CHDE HQ and Training Facility are refurbished, renovated, furnished and equipped.
to be reported in 2024

Knowledge of the CHDE leadership enhanced through participation in international events, study visits and exchange of expertise (CHDE leadership and personnel were supported to participate in four major international events/conferences in Switzerland, Belgium, Cambodia and 1 study visit to Cambodia).
Key MA stakeholders were identified and engaged in National Mine Action Coordination Platform with strong coordination mandate.
National Mine Action Coordination Platform was established and holds regular meetings.
NMACP holds regular meetings to facilitate coordination in the mine action programme and reports back to their institutions regularly.
4 working groups have been created. All key operators in Mine Action pillars are engaged in working groups.
Working groups meet on monthly basis.
Working groups meet on monthly basis.
Educational resources (9 tutorials and bilingual guidebook) on EO and mine risk education, leaflets and posters have been developed and widely distributed.
VIS is developed and operational
Mine Action Strategy and Operational Plans for 2023-2027 developed.
CHDE developed and approved the Operational Plans for upcoming 5-year period (2023-2027).
result_indicator_period_target_comment_n: The Project is in a start-up period.
75% of previously mined lands are in productive or social use.
National mine action standards are updated
CHDE is equipped with modern and up-to-date EOD and detection equipment
CHDE HQ and Training Center are renovated
CHDE HQ and Training Centre are refurbished
National Mine Action Coordination Platform established
Risk education materials and knowledge products are developed
National strategy and operational plans were developed.
